text:
Is there a builtin cross-platform solution to fix warnings like
```┌ Warning: Minimum instruction set detected for bin/rubberband is sandybridge, not x86_64 as desired.
└ @ BinaryBuilder.Auditor ~/.julia/packages/BinaryBuilder/OMMHj/src/Auditor.jl:269```
I am guessing I just need to add `-march=x86_64` to the `CXXFLAGS`, but that won't work for other platforms of course.

elements.text: Is there a builtin cross-platform solution to fix warnings like

┌ Warning: Minimum instruction set detected for bin/rubberband is sandybridge, not x86_64 as desired.
└ @ BinaryBuilder.Auditor ~/.julia/packages/BinaryBuilder/OMMHj/src/Auditor.jl:269
I am guessing I just need to add
-march=x86_64
to the
CXXFLAGS
, but that won't work for other platforms of course.

text: we already force `-march`.  there is usually little to do about those warnings, in most cases the library uses intrinsics without checking whether the CPU actually supports them

elements.text: we already force
-march
.  there is usually little to do about those warnings, in most cases the library uses intrinsics without checking whether the CPU actually supports them

text:
```% grep -r intrin
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:   the SSE2 intrinsics will be used in place of the MMX intrinsics. Do
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:#include <xmmintrin.h>
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:# include <emmintrin.h>
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:/* the ugly part below: many versions of gcc used to be completely buggy with respect to some intrinsics
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:   The movehl_ps is fixed in mingw 3.4.5, but I found out that all the _mm_cmp* intrinsics were completely
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:/* evaluation of 4 sines at onces, using only SSE1+MMX intrinsics so
src/pommier/sse_mathfun.h:   Since it is based on SSE intrinsics, it has to be compiled at -O2 to
src/kissfft/kiss_fft.h:# include <xmmintrin.h>```
